name: Celadon Figured Jar Produced by Yue Kiln
period: 年代：Wei, Jin and Southern and Northern Dynasties
intro:
Height: 46.5cm, Base Diameter: 14cm, Belly Diameter: 24.7cm
Excavated from No.1 Tomb of Shizishan, Suzhou
Western Jin Dynasty

Figured jar, also known as barn jar or soul jar, is a kind of unique grave good in the tombs of the Three Kingdoms and the Jin Dynasty in the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River in China. With decorations of multiple themes, this jar was produced using complex techniques, indicating that Yue Kiln had a high level of celadon production ability.

name: Bronze Seal with Inscriptions on Six Sides
period: 年代：Wei, Jin and Southern and Northern Dynasties
intro:
Eastern Jin Dynasty

The body of the seal is square, and there is a hole under the handle. There are carvings on the top of the handle, the body and the bottom. Seals with inscriptions on six sides were prevalent in the Eastern Jin Dynasty. There are two kinds of inscriptions. One denotes the owner’s name, style name, family and title. The other denotes the formats of different documents. With red paste, this seal may be used by the owner.

name: Celadon Rabbit-shaped Water Dropper
period: 年代：Wei, Jin and Southern and Northern Dynasties
intro:
Height: 6.1cm, Hole Diameter: 1.9cm, Belly Diameter: 9.5cm, Base Diameter: 4.0cm
Excavated from No.1 Tomb of Shizishan, Suzhou
Western Jin Dynasty

This oblate water dropper was stationery in the Western Jin Dynasty. It is in the shape of a rabbit with upright ears. During the Jin Dynasty, water droppers in the shapes of frog, rabbit and turtle were popular. This dropper was produced using several techniques, reflecting the superior celadon modeling ability of Yue Kiln during the Western Jin Dynasty.

name: Blue and White Porcelain Bowls with Flower and Bird Patterns
intro:
Mouth Diameter: 12cm, Foot Diameter: 4.2cm, Height: 6.1cm
Jiajing 

This pair of blue and white ceramic bowls is a masterpiece of the official kiln of Jiajing, Ming Dynasty. Each of the bowls features a straight mouth, circular body, relatively recessed ring foot and slightly raised center. The inner center is decorated with tree-peony with branches, and the outer surface is decorated with patterns of pomegranate flowers and birds. The base carries a six-character Jiajing reign mark in a double ring.

name: Guqin (Plucked Chinese Musical Instrument)
intro:
This instrument, similar to a flat-bottomed canoe in shape, was made of paulownia wood (Sterculia plantanifolia), and the panel is missing. The top is a square carved with rectangular chord grooves. Twelve through-holes are at the bottom of the grooves, and the chord groove in the head part is damaged. The tail bulges in the shape of the Chinese character “山(mountain)”. The body of the instrument was painted with black lacquer which has peeled off severely.

Guqin is the oldest plucked instrument in China and is a cultural treasure of the Chinese people. As a real object of musical instrument in the pre-Qin period with a clear excavation site and dating basis, it has important scientific research value and is a precious national first-class cultural relic.

name: Mirror with Cloud and Dragon Patterns
intro:
Diameter: 11.3cm

The mirror is round and with a mountain-shaped knob. The right side of the knob is decorated with a dragon flying in clouds, and the left side carries an inscription which means that the mirror was produced in the first month of the 22rd year of the reign of Emperor Hongwu. Mirrors with cloud and dragon patterns were popular in the Ming Dynasty. Apart from mirrors decorated with one dragon, those with two dragons are also widely found.

name: Shadowy Blue Melon-shaped Powder Box
intro:
Diameter: 8.6cm, Height: 5.2cm

The powder box features a melon shape with the cover and the body tightly fit with the mechanism of a snap fastener, and has a circular foot and flat bottom. The outer surface is covered by shadowy blue glaze, and the inner wall and base are unglazed. This is a typical example of Song Dynasty powder box as it has a delicate and charming shape, and is naturalistic, full and round.

name: Jade Axe
intro: This jade axe is light green with yellowish-brown spots, warm and translucent, and is identified as a nephrite. Jade axes are developed from stone axes with holes and handles, a kind of compound production tool. The corner of a shoulder was deliberately sliced with nicks left. Axes equipped with holes and handles were invented as weapons and instruments of torture. Later axes became exquisite ritual objects without using functions, scepters of nobles and symbols of military commanders.

name: Bronze Weight
intro:
Height: 9.6cm

Weight is a kind of ancient weighing apparatus, and is used to indicate the weight standard. With a bulging belly and flat bottom, it has a concave horizontal line around its shoulder, and a handle in the shape of an inverted trapezoid with a square hole. The belly carries a four-character date mark indicating that it is made during the Zhiyuan period of Yuan Dynasty.

name: White Jade in the Shape of Grapes and a Squirrel
intro: It was carved from Hetian jade, and featured delicate and exquisite texture. It was carved into a bunch of grapes with a squirrel looking around to search for food. It was well-designed and was produced by circular carving and perforation. The theme shows people’s wishes for more children.

name: Wooden Cup Imitating Rhino Horn Cup
intro:
Length: 16.4cm, Height: 9cm

With a big mouth, small foot, and a small square base, the black brown cup is decorated with five hornless dragons, scrolling cloud patterns and water eddy patterns. Hornless dragons of different postures are arranged on the rim, inner wall and belly. Scrolling cloud patterns extend from the inner wall to the belly, and water eddy patterns rotates upward from the bottom to the handle of the cup. The patterns connect with each other naturally, leaving no gap. The cup is decorated with patterns from the bottom to the rim, which is delicate and gorgeous.

name: Stone Knife with Two Holes
intro:
Length: 12.2cm, Thickness: 0.7cm, Width of Blade: 17.6cm
Excavated from the Caoxieshan Site
Liangzhu Culture of Neolithic Period

Rectangular stone knives first appeared in the late Yangshao culture period, and were excavated from several sites of Neolithic period. The sizes tend to be small, and there are one or two holes on the stone knives. Rectangular stone knives with three, five and seven holes were discovered from the Beiyinyangying Site in Nanjing. This rectangular stone knife with a flat body, a relatively long edge, a slightly short back edge and relatively curved edges is well polished.

name: Arched Jade Ornament with Parrot Heads on Two Ends
intro:
Arc Length: 8.4cm, Width: 3cm, Thickness: 0.5cm
Excavated from Yanshan
Spring and Autumn Period

The jade is light green in color, with dark green flecks within, polished and glossy. This jade ornament was made on a piece of tile-shaped raw material. The two ends of it are carved into symmetrical parrot heads in profile, with high combs and hooked beaks. The small holes are taken as parrots’ eyes. Their bodies are compressed and omitted to suit the curvature of the jade and the shape of the ornament. The beaks, eyes, and crests are highlighted, showing a kind of realism-based exaggeration. This kind of artistic design, which grasps and generalizes the core image characteristics, shows the distinct cultural style of the Wu state in the Spring and Autumn Period. This is the only one parrot-shaped jade ornament in the Pre-Qin period.

name: Bronze Gui (Container)
intro:
Height: 11.5cm, Mouth Diameter: 27.8cm, Belly Diameter: 21.5cm, Base Diameter: 14.5cm
Han Dynasty

In ancient China, Gui was used as a container for rice and millet when offering sacrifices and holding banquets. During the Western Zhou Dynasty (1046 BC-771 BC), Gui and Ding (vessel) were used to indicate the ranks of nobles. Kings used nine Ding and eight Gui, vassals used seven Ding and six Gui, ministers used five Ding and four Gui, and scholars used three Ding and two Gui. This Gui has an open mouth, a deep belly, a ring foot and a flat base, with horizontal lines around the rim and the upper belly and symmetrical beast-faced handles with ring on both sides of the belly. The overall shape of the Gui is relatively neat, reflecting the level of bronze production in the Han Dynasty to a certain extent.

name: Amber in the Shape of Two Kids
intro:
Height: 4.3cm, Width: 4.6cm, Thickness: 2cm
Guangxu

Carved from amber, the red and transparent decoration shows two children sitting and playing. The bottom carries an inscription which means that it was produced by Deaf Zhang. It vividly shows the images of two innocent and lively kids with natural expressions. Deaf Zhang was a carver of Tianjin who lived in the reign of Guangxu. He was also good at stereoscopic carving, and his works were said to be popular among people.

name: Jadeite Ornaments Excavated from Li Zhongxian’s Tomb
intro:
Bracelet: Diameter: 7.8cm,
Ring Thickness: 1.1cm,Ring: Diameter: 2.2cm
Eardrop: Height: 2.6cm
Pendant: Length: 2.1cm
Court Beads: Diameter: 1cm

This set of ornaments was discovered in the tomb of Li Jongxian and his wife. This set includes bracelets, rings, eardrops, and court beads. The shapes of these ornaments are neat and well cut, and the jadeite is pure and green.

Li Jingxi, courtesy name Zhongxian, was the nephew of Li Hongzhang. He was the viceroy of Yun-Gui in 1909. He built a house in Suzhou in his remaining years. Jadeite originated from Burma. Introduced to China in the early Qing Dynasty, it is used in many aspects such as furnishings, stationery, utensils, jewelry, which is very popular.

name: Arched Jade Ornament with a Ridge and Two Rings
intro: The body is arched and in a tile shape, with a ridge in the middle of the front side. The two sides of the ridge are decorated with bas-reliefs in animal mask patterns and bird patterns. On the two sides of the body, there are two rings, with one carved into the shape of an animal head, and the other carved into two parallel circles. A small ring is connected with the circles (the shaft has been broken) and can rotate freely. The elliptical ring at the lower end can be used to attach a ribbon. This kind of conjoined movable ring is made of a whole jade raw material, which shows the excellent jade carving skills of the craftsman at that time.

name: Secret Color Square Ceramic Plate Set
intro:
Length: 14cm, Width: 13.7cm, Height: 6.6cm
Excavated from Qizi Hill

This set of nine secret color square ceramic plates produced by Yue Kiln is of the same shape and pattern and the plates can be placed one on another. The high base is in the shape of Sumeru Mountain. The surface is covered by fine aqua glaze. Over 100 cultural relics including a secret color ceramic bowl with golden rim and gilding ornaments are excavated from the same tomb which may be the tomb of a noble of Wuyue State in the Five Dynasties.

name: Silver Raft-shaped Cup Made by Zhu Bishan
intro:
Hypotenuse Length: 22cm, Width: 7.5cm, Height: 11.4cm

This cup indicates a story of an immortal penetrating into the Milky Way by raft. Shaped like a branch, the cup has an inscription on its back that means “made by Zhu Bishan in the yiyou year of Zhizheng”. Zhu Bishan was a famous silversmith in the Yuan Dynasty.

With delicate design and unique shape, this cup is made by several techniques such as chasing, soldering, circular carving and enchasing, presenting the layers of the immortal and raft, the raft and cloud, and the immortal and branch in a clear, simple and coordinated way. The cup, with ingenious design and made by exquisite craftsmanship, reflects the high technical level of silver workmanship of the Yuan Dynasty. In this connection, this is an artistic treasure of Yuan silver.

name: Red Duck-shaped Pottery Pot
intro: This is a typical artifact of Maqiao Culture. It is made of red clay, in the shape of a duck, and decorated with horizontal lines around the rim. Maqiao Culture features clay potteries with stamped patterns made by patting and vessels with concave round bottoms. The pot was used to hold water. Some scholars believe that duck-shaped pot was invented by the people of Maqiao Culture due to their familiarity and reverence for birds as they lived in the Taihu Lake Area with warm and moist climate and rivers and marshes.

name: Lacquer Inkstone
intro:
Length: 14.9cm, Width: 9.8cm, Height: 2.7cm

The inkstone is rectangular in shape, and light black in color. With wood as the paste, the outer part is made by mixing very fine sand and moderate natural lacquer. The surface has traces of use. The weight of this inkstone is only one-fifth of that of a normal stone inkstone, and it is convenient to carry. The cover and the body tightly fit with the mechanism of a snap fastener. The cover is inlaid with plum blossom and orchid.

name: Chu Tu He
intro:
Height: 25.2cm, Height of Handle: 8.5cm, Height of Feet: 6.8cm, Mouth Diameter: 20.5cm, Weight: 4105g
Excavated from an Eastern Zhou Tomb at Heshan
Spring and Autumn Period

He, an ancient bronze wine vessel with a big belly, a contracted mouth, a long spout, a single ear, a lid, and usually three feet, was popular in the Shang Dynasty (1600 BC-1046 BC) and the early Western Zhou Dynasty (1046 BC-771 BC). The inscription on the vessel mainly means that the He belonged to Tu, descendant of Chu Shu. Tu should be a name, but this person is not recorded in history. According to the research of “Peng, descendant of Chu Shu” by Li Ling and other scholars, Peng should be Peng Zifeng. In this connection, Tu should also be a member of the royal family of Chu, and Peng Zifeng’s relative. This vessel belonged to a noble of Chu.

In 506 BC, King Helu of Wu and Wu Zixu led their troops to attack Ying, capital of Chu. Therefore, it is likely that the bronze vessel of Chu unearthed in this tomb was the spoil of war. The date of the tomb is estimated to be after the end of the war between Wu and Chu in 506 BC or later.

name: Tiger-shaped Jade Ornaments
intro:
Length: 11.9cm, Width: 3.8cm, Thickness: 0.1-0.3cm
Excavated from Yanshan
Spring and Autumn Period

The tiger-shaped jade ornaments are a pair of the same shape and size, and with their heads slightly raised on which there are holes like eyes, four legs bent, tails curled up, and back ridges carved into protruding strips. The jade color is gray and white with black. On the front side, they are obliquely incised with the variant Kui dragon design as in a bas-relief and are filled with feather shaped fine lines. The two tigers look vivid, and the decorative lines on them are rugged and powerful, demonstrating splendid craftsmanship. Tiger-shaped jade objects were called “Hu” in ancient times, and they were accessories according to archaeological findings.

name: Painted Pottery Pot with Tubular Ears
intro:
Height: 10.6cm, Mouth Diameter: 8cm
Excavated from the Chenghu Lake Site
Liangzhu Culture of Neolithic Period

This pot with tubular ears is a typical artifact of the Neolithic Liangzhu culture. There were two kinds of painted pottery at that time, namely, lacquer-painted pottery which used natural lacquer to paint patterns, and painted pottery which used natural mineral powder for painting. This pot falls into the first category. It is designed with a straight mouth, a square rim, circular shoulders, a round and bulging body, and a flat bottom. Two ox nose shaped tubular ears are arranged on both sides of the rim. The neck is painted in yellow. Its shoulder and belly are decorated with horizontal lines and wave patterns.

name: White Ceramic Ewer with Veiled Decoration
intro:
Height: 17.9cm, Mouth Diameter: 4.5cm, Belly Diameter: 9.2cm, Bottom Diameter: 6.8cm

This ewer has a dish-shaped mouth, short circular foot, pear-shaped body with flared lip, handle, and spout. The spout is slightly lower than the mouth, thus facilitating water flow. S-shaped decoration is arranged between the spout and handle. The shape is clean and delicate, the spout and handle both have smooth lines, and the glaze is thick and glossy. It is a ewer of great quality in the middle and late Ming Dynasty.

name: Celadon Ball-shaped Incense Burner Produced by Yue Kiln
period: 年代：Wei, Jin and Southern and Northern Dynasties
intro:
Height: 17.4cm, Mouth Diameter: 2.1cm, Belly Diameter: 12cm, Base Diameter: 10.8cm
Excavated from No.1 Tomb of Shizishan, Suzhou
Western Jin Dynasty

This incense burner consists of two parts. The upper part is in the shape of a hollow ball, with 64 triangular holes pierced in 5 rows and an oval input. The lower part is a holder decorated with horizontal lines and bands of lozenges. Incense burners developed from bronze censers of Han Dynasty. Incense burners were used by scholars in the Western Jin Dynasty to steam clothes and quilts. The ball-shaped body is modeled on hill censers of Han Dynasty. It is a fine celadon that combines beauty and practicality.

name: Stone Axe
intro:
Length: 12.2cm, Width: 7cm
Excavated from the Zhanglingshan Site
Liangzhu Culture of Neolithic Period

Stone axe was the most important stone tool in the Neolithic Period. They were excavated from several sites, and were used for a long time. They became thinner during transformation, and holes were arranged on them, which showed the development of social productivity. Axes with perforated holes of the Liangzhu Culture of Neolithic Period reflect the most advanced technology at that time. Some sort of rotating tool was introduced for cutting holes.

name: Ivory Brush Pot with Carved Travelers among Mountains and Streams
intro:
Height: 12.1cm, Mouth Diameter: 7.9cm, Bottom Diameter: 7.4cm

This brush pot is made of ivory. It is carved by  high relief into Travelers among Mountains and Streams, resembling a slowly unfolding long scroll. With mountains overlapping, it is rich in content and reasonable in layout, with vivid and naturalistic figures, and harmonious scenery. This style of carving, with its steep, majestic and robust atmosphere, creates a feeling of beauty and clarity, and fully reflects the artistic charm of ivory carving in the Qing Dynasty.

name: Bronze Sword
intro: The bronze sword is a kind of short weapon, which can be held or worn. The earliest known swords are from the early Western Zhou Dynasty (1046 BC-771 BC). Swords gradually increased in number during the Spring and Autumn Period (770 BC-476 BC), and by the late Spring and Autumn Period, the Wuyue region was particularly famous for sword production. This bronze sword is well produced and preserved. The sword consists of a body (“shen”), flats (“cong”) and a haft (“jing”). The haft is also known as the handle. The body comprises a ridge (“ji”), and edges (“e”). Between the grip and the body, there is a guard (“ge”) to protect hands.

name: Celadon Pot with Dish-shaped Mouth
intro:
Han Dynasty

With a round rim, a dish-shaped mouth, a bulging belly, and a flat bottom, the pot is tall and thin. The shoulder is decorated with two opposite ears with fern patterns. The shoulder and belly have horizontal lines left by the spinning of the paste. The fire temperature was high when the jar was completed, and the porcelain is hard, beige and unglazed. The surface of the jar is relatively rough, embodying the characteristics of the porcelain of early Eastern Han Dynasty (25-220).

name: Celadon Bull Barn
period: 年代：Wei, Jin and Southern and Northern Dynasties
intro:
Western Jin Dynasty

This celadon cow barn is designed with a cylinder shape, round rim, straight wall, flat bottom, fifteen hollowed rectangular holes, rhomboid-form patterns around the barn, and a hole for feeding. It is decorated with a bull inside the barn, lying next to a trough. The surface is covered with a green glaze. This celadon cow barn is produced with several methods, reflecting the mature production technique of celadon. In the tombs of the great families of Western Jin Dynasty, a wide variety of grave goods made of celadon including bull barns, dog kennels, chicken nests, barn jars and wells are unearthed, showing that nobles and great families at that time occupied a wide range of fertile farmlands and raised livestock.

name: Jade Jue (Slit Ring)
intro:
External Diameter: 4.6 cm, Ring Width: 1.5cm, Thickness: 0.6cm
Excavated from the Yuecheng Site, Majiabang Culture of Neolithic Period

Slit rings look like a ring with a slit. They were first discovered in the Majiabang Culture and a representative kind of jade artifacts. Often founded beside the ears of the dead, they should be a kind of earring. This slit ring is milky white, and in the shape of an oblate ring. There is a round hole in the middle of it with various diameters. It’s well-polished and without patterns.

name: Bird-shaped Pot with a Handle
intro: This pot is made of black pottery and in the shape of a bird. The surface of the black pottery has peeled off. The Yue people used to revere birds as their ancestors and took birds as their totem. Vessels made in the shape of birds are for using and appreciation. This kind of bird-shaped pot with a handle is a typical artifact of Liangzhu Culture, and was excavated from several sites of Liangzhu Culture such as Caoxieshan and Meiyan in Suzhou and Fuquanshan in Shanghai.

name: Bronze Mirror Decorated with Mythical Birds and Auspicious Animals
intro: The mirror is made of bronze. The front is a shiny polished surface and can be used as a mirror, and the back is decorated with patterns or inscriptions. The mirror is in the shape of a water chestnut flower with eight petals. In the middle, a prostrate animal is depicted. In the outer part of this mirror, there are bird patterns, butterfly patterns and flower and plant patterns. In the inner part, it is decorated with patterns of mythical birds and auspicious animals. There are also patterns of interlocking lotus. This kind of bronze mirror was very popular in the Tang Dynasty, and appeared under Wu Zetian’s reign.

name: Bronze Spear
intro:
Length: 15.6cm
Eastern Zhou Dynasty

Spear was a piercing weapon for jabbing in ancient times. A spear head consists of two parts: a body (“shen”) and a socket (“xiao”). The body has a shape blade and the central line is called ridge (“ji”). The socket is hollow and conical, and is used to insert a shaft (“bi”). There are often ears on both sides of the socket. The bronze ornaments fastened to the end of the shaft are flat-bottomed metal caps (“dui”). From the Shang Dynasty (1600 BC-1046 BC) to the Spring and Autumn (770 BC-476 BC) and Warring States (475 BC-221 BC) periods, the development of spears was popular. Spears were used on chariots. Most of the weapons of the Eastern Zhou Dynasty handed down from ancient times and found in archaeological excavations are swords. As this well-preserved and sharp bronze spear is in a regular shape and was created with outstanding casting technique, it is a rare treasure.

name: Celadon Flat Pot Produced by Yue Kiln
period: 年代：Wei, Jin and Southern and Northern Dynasties
intro:
Height: 25.8cm, Mouth Diameter: 5.4cm, Width of Belly: 23cm, Width of Base: 19cm
Excavated from No.1 Tomb of Shizishan, Suzhou
Western Jin Dynasty

Flat flask is a kind of water container. With a flat and round body, a square rim and a straight mouth, it is decorated with a concave horizontal line, and its shoulder is decorated with bands of circles and lozenges. There are two decorations in the shape of beast face with ring on its belly.

This flask was excavated from a tomb of Western Jin Dynasty. A brick inscribed with “Yuankan”, an era name of Emperor Hui of Jin was unearthed too. In this connection, this object has an absolute date. It is of great historical, artistic, and cultural relic value with its simple shape, delicate decorations and exquisite production.

name: White Porcelain Jar with Two Rings
intro:
Mouth Diameter: 3.1cm, Belly Diameter: 5.5cm, Bottom Diameter: 1.6cm, Height: 4.8cm

White porcelain is a kind of porcelain with white paste and glaze made by high temperature firing. It has a wide flared mouth, a round and bulging body, and two rings on the shoulder. With a small shape and clear glaze, this jar is a fine object of white porcelain.

name: Cloisonne Vases with Dragon Patterns
intro:
A pair, Height: 10.9cm, 10.4cm, Mouth Diameter: 1.1cm, 1.7cm, Base Diameter: 4.1cm, 3.5cm

This pair of vases has basically the same size, shape and patterns. With a straight mouth, square rim, long and thin neck, ring foot, and flat bottom, each of the vases is decorated with plantain leaf pattern around the rim, and water pattern on the lower belly near the ring foot. The belly of each vase is decorated with a dragon pursuing a pearl among clouds. The two dragons are glazed in similar colors including blue, green, red and yellow. This pair of vases is a classic work of cloisonné.

name: Twisted Glass Snuff Bottle
intro:
Height: 6.8cm, Mouth Diameter: 1.7cm, Base Diameter: 2.1cm
Qianlong 

The bottle has a small round mouth, straight neck, circular shoulder, and flat base. The yellow and white glass present stripe patterns which resemble wood texture and waterfall, and has ever-changing dynamic beauty. With a standard shape and impressive patterns, this bottle is a precious one. Twisted glass snuff bottles are made by blowing glass with more than two colors. People like them due to the special twisted patterns.

name: Mammal Fossils of the Sanshan Island
intro: The mammal fossils of the Sanshan Island are roughly dated between 21,500 and 12,300 years ago. The presence of a large number of mammalian fauna and paleogeographic studies indicate that Sanshan Island was not a small island on Taihu Lake at that time, but was integrated with the present land around Taihu Lake and was a plain and hilly terrain with lush trees on the hills, grasslands all over the plains, flocks of animals, and a colder climate than today. A large number of animal fossils were excavated, including fossils of tigers, rhinoceroses, spotted hyenas, brown bears, black bears, lynxes, wolves, badgers, porcupines, skunks, macaques, tapirs, deer, cows, rabbits, etc.

name: Jade Bi (Disk) Carved with a Symbol
intro: This jade disk is well-polished. On one side of the disk, there is a tiny symbol which looks similar to a perforated Yue (axe). According to studies, only 11 jade disks with symbol are discovered. Before this disk was excavated, the only one disk with a clear excavation site is the one excavated in Baimu Mountain, Anxi Town, Yuhang District, Zhejiang Province.

name: Bronze Fu (Container)
intro: In ancient China, Fu was used as a container for rice, millet, sorghum, rice and other food when offering sacrifices and holding banquets. Rectangular in shape and supported by try square-shaped feet, the Fu consists of a lid and a body of the same shape and size. The lid and the body can be used as two vessels. Fu appeared in the early Western Zhou Dynasty (1046 BC-771 BC), mainly prevailed in the late Western Zhou Dynasty and the early Spring and Autumn Period (770 BC-476 BC), and disappeared after the late Warring States Period (475 BC-221 BC).

name: Bronze Wei and Xia (Axle Cap and Pin)
intro: Wei and Xia are both components of ancient Chinese chariots. Wei shapes like a cylinder, and is mounted at both ends of the axle. Xia is inserted through a hole on the Wei and a hole on the end of the axle to secure the Wei. To enhance the antipersonnel force of chariots, a spear blade was often installed on Wei.

name: Cup with Veiled Decoration Produced by Official Kiln of Southern Song Dynasty
intro: This cup features crackled glaze, veiled phoenix pattern in the center under the glaze, purple thinly-glazed mouth, and rust-colored unglazed foot. Ceramics produced by the official kiln of Southern Song Dynasty (1127-1279) are characterized by thin paste, thick glaze, purple mouth, and rust-colored foot. Only a few items of the Southern Song official kiln remain preserved to date. This cup, with Southern Song official kiln characteristics of thin paste, thick glaze, crackled glaze, purple mouth, and rust-colored foot, is quite precious.

name: Tri-colored Ewer with Phoenix Head-shaped Handle
intro:
Height: 17.35cm, Mouth Diameter: 6cm, Belly Diameter: 9.8cm, Base Diameter: 5.8cm

Tri-colored wares are a type of lead-glazed earthenware fired at a lower temperature. With a dish-shaped mouth, bulging body, two horizontal lines around the neck, a handle in the shape of phoenix’s head linking the rim and the upper belly, and a phoenix’s head on the other side of the shoulder, the ewer is covered with yellow, green and brown glazes.

Ewers with phoenix’s head handle were popular during Sui and Tang Dynasties. Tri-colored wares appeared in the early Tang Dynasty, and declined in the late Tang Dynasty. They are distributed in the tombs of Tang Dynasty in Xi’an, Luoyang, Yangzhou and other cities. Most of them are grave goods and there are also objects for daily use and architectural components.

name: Shadowy Blue Powder Boxes
intro:
①Diameter: 8.9cm, Height: 5.2cm; ②Diameter: 3.7cm, Height: 2.0cm
Excavated from a tomb of Song Dynasty in Cangshu Town
Southern Song Dynasty

This set of powder boxes includes a big one and a small one. The covers both fit the bodies perfectly in the way like the snap fastener. With white and delicate paste and green glaze, they feature unglazed rims and bottoms. There is no other decoration on their surfaces. Some shadowy blue porcelain and celadon boxes consist of four boxes: a big box and three small boxes. With such boxes, powder, black pigment and bright red pigment can be respectively put in the small boxes placed in the large one, which is more convenient to use.

name: Underglaze Red Covered Jar with Cloud and Dragon Patterns
intro:
Height: 38.2cm, Mouth Diameter: 12.7cm, Belly Diameter: 25cm, Bottom Diameter: 13.7cm

Underglaze is a method of decorating pottery in which painted decoration is applied to the surface before it is covered with a transparent ceramic glaze and fired in a kiln. The red color is achieved by copper in reduction firing. Since copper is volatile at high temperature, the production of the red color requires strict temperature control. Therefore, the production of such ceramics is dramatically difficult. This jar with cloud and dragon patterns and a lid, with two dragons carved on its belly, is of graceful shape, unique decorations and bright color. Few masterpieces of underglaze red ceramics are preserved to date, and this one is a national treasure.

name: Painted Pot with Two Rings Produced by Changsha Kiln
intro:
Mouth Diameter: 8.6cm,
Bottom Diameter: 10.6cm,
Height: 16.4cm

The painted pot with two rings produced by Changsha Kiln has a straight mouth, high neck, and slightly bulging body decorated with brown lotus petal patterns and green round spots in the center.

Changsha Kiln, also known as Tongguan Kiln, is located in Tongguan Town, Changsha City, Hunan Province. Changsha Kiln started to fire wares in Tang Dynasty, and flourished in the late Tang Dynasty to Five Dynasties. Products including jars, pots and bowls were produced, and they are characterized by brown and green paintings, applied designs and poem decorations.

name: Blue and White Ceramic Plate with Lotus Pattern
intro: The plate is produced by the official kiln of Jingdezhen in the reign of Xuande in the Ming Dynasty. The plate has a round rim, open mouth, ring foot and flat bottom, following the style of the late Yuan and early Ming dynasties. It is painted in the center with a bunch of lotus flowers and leaves tied with a ribbon. The scrolling grass patterns are around the rim inside and outside. Imported Samarra blue cobalt which was rich in iron was used to produce blue and white ceramics, yielding a glaze with darker blue spots. The plate, with its standard shape, simple composition, distinctive theme, and rich color, is one of the finest objects produced by the official kiln of Jingdezhen in the reign of Xuande.

name: Padauk Wood Carved God of Longevity
intro:
Height: 57cm

Carved from padauk wood, the object is in the shape of the God of Longevity in an upright posture with prominent cranium and the head slightly to the left. With a big smile on his face, he holds a walking stick, and the stick end is tied with a gourd by a ribbon. The facial features of the God of Longevity are created by circular carving, and the natural texture of wood is used to decorate his jacket. The facial expressions of the God of Longevity are meticulously carved, and other parts are simple.

name: Stone Plough with Two Blades
intro: It is made of grayish-white shale, in the shape of triangle, and with a pair of drilled circular perforations at the front end of the body. Only the blades are finely ground, and other parts are relatively rough. By pushing the stone plough vertically, it can break up the soil, which distinguishes it from the flat triangular stone plough. The size of stone ploughs is often large, and the stones used for making them are usually sandstone and shale. These stones are widely distributed and easily accessible, and their unique sedimentary laminate structure makes them easy to be peeled and shaped into large pieces, while their relatively low hardness makes them easy to be ground. In terms of the manufacturing process, it should go through a number of processes such as material selection, shaping, rough grinding, fine grinding of the blades, and drilling.

name: Shadowy Blue Lion and Elephant Shaped Candle Stickers
intro: This is a pair of candle stickers of the same size and texture, and slightly different shapes. One candle sticker is in the shape of a lion putting out legs, standing with its head raised, and decorated with comb patterns under the glaze of its fur. The other one is in the shape of an elephant standing with its head bent, staring with bulging eyes, rolling its trunk inward, and decorated with a cross bride on its head. Each of the candle stickers has a hollow belly with two small circular holes of 1.0cm in diameter underneath the belly, and back set with a cylindrical base with scrolling flowers. With vivid shapes and lustrous color, this pair of candle stickers is a rare treasure.

name: Jade Bead Bangles with Gold Wires
intro: This pair of jade bangles is made of white jade, and has a mild texture. The beads are arranged in a regular manner, and are fixed with gold wires. Each bead has gold money-shaped ornaments above and below it, and the ornaments are connected. The bangles are in the shape of a large ring worn around the wrist.

name: 石戈
Celadon Ram
period: 年代：Wei, Jin and Southern and Northern Dynasties
intro:
Length: 15.5cm,Height: 13.7cm
Eastern Jin Dynasty

The ram is crouching, with a slightly plump body and quill-patterns on its ribs. The surface is covered with a green glaze. It should be used in rituals.
Celadon rams are common from the Three Kingdoms (220-280) to the Eastern Jin Dynasty (317-420). In ancient China, ram was considered as an auspicious animal, making celadon rams popular.

name: 朱庇特胸像
intro:
朱庇特胸像

大理石

公元2世纪

高65厘米，宽45厘米，长35厘米

法尔内塞收藏，编号6275


雕像中的朱庇特有着波浪般的头发和胡子，额头饱满，鼻梁挺直，面容威严。朱庇特是罗马神话中的众神之王，也是卡皮托里山三主神之一，另外两位主神是众神之后朱诺和智慧女神密涅瓦。朱庇特相当于古希腊的宙斯，大部分有关宙斯的神话都移植到了朱庇特身上，其中很多是那些让他妻子朱诺妒火中烧的情史。
